text: Hey everyone. It's that time of year when
most of us are headed home for a little
family time and a lot of turkey, so we've
rustled up some greatest hits for you
to enjoy while you gobble down your
turkey dinner. First up here's how
chemistry makes deep-fried turkeys
super tasty. Just remember to fry it
safely. Why turkey fry? The answer
is simple: speed, texture, and flavor. A
turkey can be perfectly cooked in under
an hour because deep-frying cooks food
double-time. First, hot oil flows around
your bird, heating the exterior in a
process called convection that
evaporates out the moisture in the skin.
This gives it a nice crispy crust
blessed with a delectable maillard
reaction alongside other bold flavor
compounds from the oil. Then due to the
direct contact heat transfer of
convection, the turkey cooks itself from
the outside in via conduction. By the way
that crust keeps your bird extra juicy
by trapping moisture inside. But if
you're worried about the tryptophan in
turkey putting you to sleep, don't be.
It's true that tryptophan is used by
your body to make chemicals associated
with sleepiness. The body uses tryptophan
to make serotonin, a brain chemical that
promotes feelings of well-being and
relaxation. Serotonin is used in the body
to make melatonin, which helps control
the body's sleep and waking cycles. With
tryptophan so tied up in the production
of these pleasurable sleep-inducing
chemicals it's no wonder it gets the
blame for the bleary-eyed days after a
Thanksgiving meal. But it's not the main
culprit when it comes to post-prandial
grogginess. It's actually the huge
helpings of carbohydrates found in bread,
yams, stuffing, and slices of pumpkin pie
that caused the post meal grogginess, not
tryptophan. Overeating makes you sleepy
and sluggish. Thanks to a combination of
your body's hunger signals and a
straight up folder-bursting tummy. Part
of the reason is physical: your stomach
can stretch to a volume of about one
liter. That's about the size of a burrito.
When you eat a big meal, you fill your
stomach to its limits squeezing against
your other organs and making your
abdomen feel, well, full. The other part of
feeling full is mental. When you've had
enough to eat, the body's messenger
molecules' hormones let the brain know
it's time to stop. When you eat a
high-calorie meal cells in your
intestines secrete a hormone called
peptide tyrosine tyrosine or PYY.
When PYY reaches the brain, it binds with
receptors that give you the feeling that
you're full, maybe even a little queasy.
Some hormones react more strongly to
meals heavy in fats, carbohydrates, or
proteins, but they all serve the same
purpose: to get you to put down that fork.
So now you know. Enjoy your holiday feast
but remember to pump the brakes every
now and then. Thanks for watching. You can
check out the full videos in the video
description, and remember to share,
subscribe, and hit the bell so you'll
know when we're back from our feasting-
induced comas next week.
[Music]
